awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Physiological and molecular mechanisms that explain reproductive-female-specific skeletal growth in a highly cooperative mammal, the Damaraland mole rat
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID award takes advantage of an ongoing experiment in the Kalahari Desert of South Africa on the Damaraland mole rat, a highly social mammal that cooperatively raises its young. The goal is to test hypotheses about how breeding drives bone growth and remodeling in females. Two bones that do and do not elongate in reproductive female mole rats (lumbar vertebrae and femur, respectively), and the same bones in nonreproductive females, will be compared for bone growth and bone-derived stem cell activity, mineralization potential, gene expression, and responsiveness to hormonal signals. The project will provide new information about how hormonal signals and hormonally-mediated gene expression changes result in bone growth that is related to fitness in this unusually cooperative mammal. Results will be broadly applicable to understanding the control of skeletal remodeling and growth in mammals. The project involves training of a postdoctoral fellow and volunteers at the Kalahari Research Centre in South Africa, and public education at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. 


This project will provide novel insight into the physiological and genomic targets of social evolution in the Damaraland mole rat. In females of this eusocial species, secondary skeletal growth (lumbar vertebrae elongation and widening of the pelvic girdle) is a function of reproductive activity and results in increased litter sizes. The project will investigate gene regulatory differences in bone-forming mesenchymal stem cells that explain this breeding female-specific growth phenotype. It will test the hypothesis that estrogen and insulin-like growth factor signaling differentiate reproductive females and non-breeders, and bones that experience secondary growth from those that do not. Differences in stem cell gene expression and chromatin accessibility at estrogen-receptor transcription-factor binding sites will be quantified. By elucidating the physiological mechanisms underlying permanent, secondary skeletal growth in mole rat females, the results will lead to a better understanding of how skeletal growth in adult mammals, including humans, is controlled.

por.por_cntn:
Highly cooperative animals are often distinguished by reproductive division of labor, in which only a subset of individuals in a social group have young. In these species, breeding animals and non-breeding animals often differ in other respects as well: for example, in ants, the body mass of queens can be up to 25x that of workers. These differences are examples of remarkable plasticity, defined as the ability of the same genotypes to produce variable trait values. In the case of cooperative societies, plasticity is affected by an individual’s social role. While the physiological and molecular basis of social role-based plasticity has been intensively studied in social insects, we know comparatively little about the mechanisms that produce social role-specific traits in vertebrates. To address this gap, this study investigated cellular, molecular, and physiological aspects of social role-specific bone growth in the cooperatively breeding Damaraland mole rat.

Specifically, we took advantage of a recently completed experiment in which female Damaraland mole rats were experimentally assigned to be either breeders or non-breeders. Although all females were adults, those who became breeders experienced bone-specific resurgent growth, in which their lumbar vertebrae elongated, but not the long bones in their legs. Our study investigated how the 3-D morphology and cellular composition of bones from the vertebrae differed between breeders and non-breeders, and between vertebrae and long bones. We also isolated bone cells crucial to generating new bone structure (bone mesenchymal stem cells) to investigate social role-associated differences in gene regulation, including in response to estradiol, a potent hormonal signal involved in bone growth. Together, the resulting data sets provide unique and complementary information on the cellular structure, shape, growth potential, and molecular basis of skeletal plasticity in this highly cooperative mammal.

Broader impacts of the work include provision of training opportunities at multiple levels of scientific research, including a post-doctoral fellow, two research technicians, and two undergraduates. These opportunities have contributed to human resource development and increased diversity in science. Our data sets have also contributed to the development of new computational methods for image analysis and shape analysis, which have generalizable applications beyond the goals of this study. Finally, all data sets generated through this research will be made freely available to the public.
